stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on modeling and platforming design for a new ice level (Course 13), tested it on real N64 hardware to diagnose and fix bugs, and discussed the project's nearing completion. A significant portion of the stream was also dedicated to his live-reaction commentary of the F3 fangame showcase.

development_findings.summary: The project is nearing completion, with the current level (Course 13) expected to be finished within a month, leaving only two more levels to create.
development_findings.quote: I hope I can finish this level in the next month or so and then it's just two levels missing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified that the large size of Course 13 causes a major camera rendering bug on real N64 hardware. His short-term fix is to shrink the level, but he acknowledges a custom code solution may be necessary.
development_findings.quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this. It usually does that when you have a really big area. I might have to invent a solution to that problem.

development_findings.summary: The game now has a functional anti-aliasing option on real N64 hardware and maintains a framerate of 45-46 FPS in a visually complex area with it enabled.
development_findings.quote: This is with anti-aliasing on. 46. 45 to 46.

development_findings.summary: After testing a section and finding a jump 'a little awkward' and the difficulty 'kind of difficult,' Kaze immediately adjusted the 3D geometry to improve the player experience.
Kaze encountered a technical limitation with a pre-existing graphics 'combiner' for a snow effect, preventing him from achieving the desired look. He decided to abandon it and create a new one later.
development_findings.quote: This snow combiner is way too messed up to work with. I'm gonna have to make up something new.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has successfully implemented what he describes as 'infinite render distance' in the 'Bunny Brush' level, a significant technical achievement on the N64.
development_findings.quote: This level has infinite drawing distance even on 64.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explicitly states he will not use the F3 fangame showcase, which he organizes, to promote his own projects.
development_findings.quote: My game never will show up in F3... I'd rather just release them, you know.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes ROM hacks are creatively superior to many mainstream games because they are free from commercial pressures, which often force official titles to be 'bland' to maximize sales.
context_findings.quote: ROM hacks don't have to sell well. So ROM hacks can get a little more creative. Because when you have to sell well, you have to make something somewhat bland.

context_findings.summary: Kaze strongly disagrees with the idea that fan game developers should hide their work to avoid C&Ds, arguing that obscurity is a form of self-sabotage and that promotion is essential.
context_findings.quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it and you don't show anyone, you CND'd yourself. Why are you doing Nintendo's job for them?

context_findings.summary: Kaze's artistic philosophy is to focus on creating a specific feeling for the player, rather than adhering to formal art principles which he feels are for critics, not audiences.
context_findings.quote: You don't want to operate on principles because if you operate on principles, you make art for critics, you don't make art for the sake of it being experienced.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally embeds project updates and level previews within technical videos, as he believes his audience prefers technical content and dislikes spoilers from standalone previews.
context_findings.quote: I have to hide them under actual technical videos. So that you can see the level. And you see that there's progress. But also you have a reason to watch the video.

context_findings.summary: Kaze humorously expresses the depth of his creative investment in the project shortly after becoming a new father.
context_findings.quote: Somehow I'm more proud of this than of the child. What can I say? I'm an artist.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to create and sell physical boxes and manuals for the game, carefully avoiding Nintendo IP to remain legal, while anticipating that third parties will produce unofficial cartridges.
context_findings.quote: I am not allowed to sell real cartridges... But what I am planning to do is make a box and a book inlet without any Nintendo references to it and put that out so you can at least get the box as a souvenir.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on becoming a father, acknowledging that while his mother-in-law's help has made it manageable, the workload likely falls more heavily on his wife, Zeina.
context_findings.quote: Everyone was always talking about how having a child is so much work. And sure, it's a bit of work, but currently Zeina's mom is helping us and honestly, it doesn't feel like that much, although it's probably a lot more work for Zeina than for me.

biobak.summary: Biobak was responsible for the concept and 3D model of the Fuzzies wearing protective gear.
biobak.quote: This was Biobak's idea and Biobak made the model. They're now wearing protective gear.

biobak.summary: When a viewer praised the game's art and colors, Kaze deferred the credit, suggesting the viewer was appreciating Biobak's contributions.
biobak.quote: Maybe you like Biobak's part more than mine.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze's newborn daughter, Reyna, is being cared for by Zeina and her mother, indicating a family support system is present.
zeina.quote: She is currently upstairs with Zeina's mom.

zeina.summary: Kaze confirms that Zeina, who is also the project's animator, is still involved and will likely appear on stream again, though her presence is currently limited due to her new parental responsibilities.
zeina.quote: I'm sure Zeina is going to show up at least a few times again.

key_stories.title: The Big Level Camera Glitch
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered a show-stopping camera bug on the N64 caused by a level being too large. He diagnosed the problem and implemented an immediate, practical workaround by shrinking the level, demonstrating his iterative problem-solving approach while tabling a more complex fix for later.
key_stories.challenge: A major camera glitch was discovered when testing a new, large level on real N64 hardware, causing the screen to become a garbled mess because the frame buffer was not clearing properly.
key_stories.process: Kaze first identified the issue during a hardware test. He immediately hypothesized the cause was the level's large scale. To solve it, he returned to his 3D modeling software and scaled down parts of the level to bring them closer together.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a temporary fix by shrinking the level's geometry, which mitigated the issue enough to continue development. The need for a more robust, custom-coded solution for large levels remains a future task.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this. It usually does that when you have a really big area. I might have to invent a solution to that problem.

key_stories.title: F3 is for the Community, Not Me
key_stories.summary: When asked why his own game wasn't in the F3 showcase, Kaze articulated his philosophy that the event is purely for community benefit. He positions himself as a facilitator providing 'free marketing' to other modders, intentionally separating his role as a host from his work as a developer.
key_stories.challenge: Throughout the F3 fangame showcase that Kaze was hosting, viewers repeatedly questioned why his own highly anticipated project was not being featured.
key_stories.process: Kaze repeatedly stated that his own hacks would never appear in F3. He framed the event as a service to the community, designed to give exposure to other developers and combat the fear of C&Ds by encouraging open promotion.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze firmly established F3 as a community-first platform, using his influence to elevate other creators rather than for self-promotion. He plans to expand the event's reach next year to help even more developers.
key_stories.key_quote: We want to provide free marketing. Make sure everyone knows about all the coolest new mods coming up so we can all enjoy these free games.

open_questions.context: Kaze pitched a video idea about how some of Nintendo's own optimizations in the original Super Mario 64 code actually made the game run slower.
questions: What are the most surprising examples of Nintendo's optimizations that were actually counter-productive?
How did you discover these inefficiencies?
What have you done in your engine to correct or improve upon these original Nintendo 'optimizations'?

open_questions.context: Kaze is the lead developer, but he credited Biobak with both the concept and model for the Fuzzies with protective gear and also suggested the game's lauded color palettes might be more Biobak's work.
questions: What is the typical creative workflow between you and Kaze for a new level's visual identity?
Could you tell us the story behind the Fuzzies in protective gear? What inspired that idea?
How do you approach creating new art and color palettes that feel fresh but still respect the N64's aesthetic and technical limitations?

open_questions.context: Kaze and Zeina (the animator) just had their first child. Kaze mentioned his mother-in-law is helping and acknowledged the workload is likely greater for Zeina.
questions: How has becoming new parents affected your creative collaboration and the development schedule for the project?
How do you balance the demands of the project with your new family life?
Zeina, what has your animation workflow been like, and has it changed recently?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned he plans to sell a physical box and manual for the game, but not a cartridge, as a way to offer a legal souvenir to fans.
questions: What legal considerations and creative challenges are involved in producing physical merchandise for a ROM hack?
What is your vision for the box art and manual? What feeling do you want them to evoke?
Why is it important for you to offer a physical artifact for a digital fan creation?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that after he finishes the current level (Course 13), there will only be two levels left to create for the entire game.
questions: Can you share any concepts or themes for the final two unrevealed levels?
What do you anticipate will be the biggest challenges in creating these last two courses?
How does it feel to be so close to completing the level design for the entire project?
